metadata.titleEn: South-East Tibetan plateau Station of Chinese Academy of Sciences: basic meteorological data in the station (2021)
metadata.description: The meteorological data is located at the South-East Tibetan plateau Station for integrated observation and research of alpine environment，CAS(94.738286 ° E, 29.76562 ° N, 3326 m) of the observation of air temperature, relative humidity and air pressure, wind speed, precipitation and other basic meteorological data, underlying surface for forest grassland.The original data of time resolution for 10 min, temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and air pressure is obtained by calculating arithmetic mean, precipitation for cumulative value.Weather stations set up at the end of 2006, in August 2020 to probe for the replacement, please note that when using the instrument probe models before and after the update is as follows: temperature and humidity sensor model for HMP155 by HMP45C replacement;Pressure probe model for PTB110 by PTB220 replacement;Wind speed sensor type b change from 034 to 0513, the rain sensor measuring cylinder model hasn't changed are RG13H.The data available in meteorology, atmospheric environment and ecological studies of students and researchers use (note: when using must use the data in the article from the Chinese Academy of Sciences to hide the southeast mountain environment comprehensive observation Station, South - East sect plateau Station for integrated observation and research of alpine environment, CAS)

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zones due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components, forming typical mountain vertical belts. The Sejila Mountain in southeastern Tibet has obvious characteristics of mountain vertical zones: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, there are broadleaf forests, mixed coniferous and broadleaf forests, coniferous forests, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are rich, and the longevity of trees is long (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the changes in temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in this region and its vicinity are based on the Baji Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical temperature lapse rate across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain, but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes in the region. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological modeling in this watershed area.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, in the meteorological stations of the Sejila Mountain, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and the number of high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this study.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records (April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet and two stations at the tree line (as shown in Figure 1 and Table 1). Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to slope orientation: the west slope (south slope) and the east slope (north slope), with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the west and east slopes. The vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient estimates are obtained through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and temperature or precipitation amounts.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Sejila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60 °C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72 °C·(100 m)^-1, with 2016 also having the lowest λ and 2014 the highest. The average λ for the western slope from 2013 to 2018 was 0.71 °C·(100 m)^-1. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1. Unlike the Sejila Mountain and the western slope, the lowest λ for the eastern slope occurred in 2015, while the highest was in 2017. The average λ for the eastern slope from 2013 to 2018 was 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with the precipitation during the monsoon period showing a trend of first increasing, then decreasing, and then increasing again with altitude; during the non-monsoon period, the trend changed to first decreasing and then increasing. The precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibet station was notably significant.

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the meteorological stations located for collecting data on temperature and precipitation gradients in the South-East Tibetan plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: South-East Tibetan plateau Station, Bayi, Nyingchi, Bomê

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how weather stations collect and process basic meteorological data in high-altitude environments?
Example.Answer: The weather station located at the South-East Tibetan plateau Station for integrated observation and research of alpine environment (94.738286°E, 29.76562°N, 3326m) collects data such as temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation, and pressure. The original data has a time resolution of 10 minutes, and averages are calculated for temperature, humidity, wind speed, and pressure, while precipitation is recorded as a daily accumulation.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge in estimating vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in the Sejila Mountain area is the influence of various factors on these gradients. Most meteorological stations, except for a few, are located in valleys, and the number of stations on the western slope and at high altitudes is limited, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of a dataset that records basic meteorological data at high altitudes?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation, air pressure, regular intervals, daily cumulative values, specific geographic locations, unique environmental conditions, equipment upgrades

Feature Specification.Question: What features define the methodology for assessing temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: data from multiple meteorological stations at different altitudes, categorized into natural geographic units based on orientation, regression analysis, rates of temperature decrease with altitude, rates of precipitation change with altitude, daily temperature and precipitation values collected over several years

Feature Specification.Question: What are the factors that could impact the accuracy of vertical gradient estimations in high-altitude meteorological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: geographical placement of meteorological stations, number of stations at higher altitudes, changes in environmental conditions, changes in station equipment

Quantification.Question: What is the time resolution of the original meteorological data collected at the South-East Tibetan plateau station?
How many years of temperature and precipitation data are available for the stations in the South-East Tibetan plateau from 2013 to 2018?

Definition.Question: What does '气温垂直递减率' mean in the context of meteorological studies in mountainous regions?
Definition.Answer: In the context of meteorological studies in mountainous regions, '气温垂直递减率' refers to the rate at which temperature decreases with increasing altitude. It is an important factor in understanding the vertical temperature gradients in mountainous areas like the 色季拉山, where different stations measure temperature changes at various altitudes.

Definition.Question: What is meant by '降水梯度' in the analysis of meteorological data?
Definition.Answer: '降水梯度' refers to the variation in precipitation with altitude. In the analysis of meteorological data, it is used to understand how precipitation levels change as elevation increases, which is critical for studying patterns in regions with diverse topographies, such as the 色季拉山 area.

Definition.Question: What does '气温和降水量数据的垂直变化规律' imply in research studies focusing on mountain slopes?
Definition.Answer: '气温和降水量数据的垂直变化规律' implies the study of how temperature and precipitation data change vertically along mountain slopes. This involves analyzing data from different meteorological stations to understand the influence of slope orientation and altitude on these variables, as seen in the research conducted in the 色季拉山 region.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method for basic meteorological data at the South-East Tibetan plateau Station compare to the methods used for collecting temperature and precipitation data across the 11 meteorological stations in the region?
Comparison.Answer: The South-East Tibetan plateau Station collects basic meteorological data such as temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation, and pressure with a 10-minute time resolution, using sensors that were upgraded in 2020. In contrast, the data from the 11 meteorological stations focus on temperature and precipitation data, using daily values collected from 2013-2018, for exploring temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced when collecting meteorological data in the South-East Tibetan plateau compared to the challenges in studying temperature and precipitation gradients on the Sejila Mountain slopes?
Comparison.Answer: Both data collection efforts face challenges related to the terrain and location. The South-East Tibetan plateau Station deals with sensor upgrades and ensuring data precision over time. The Sejila Mountain study faces challenges from the limited number of high-altitude stations and the influence of geographical features, such as valleys, which may affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Interpretation.Question: What considerations should be made when estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across mountain slopes with varying station distribution?
Interpretation.Answer: When estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, it's important to consider the geographical positioning and altitude of each station. In areas where stations are predominantly located in valleys, as opposed to ridges, the data might not fully represent high-altitude conditions. Additionally, limited data from certain slopes or high-altitude stations could skew the results, highlighting the need for a balanced distribution of measurement points.

Interpretation.Question: How can regression analysis be applied to infer climate patterns from meteorological data collected over different altitudes and slopes?
Interpretation.Answer: Regression analysis can be used to derive relationships between altitude and climate variables like temperature and precipitation. By analyzing data from various stations, researchers can estimate how these variables change with altitude. This approach helps identify unique patterns, such as differentiated lapse rates on east and west slopes, and provides insights into microclimatic variations influenced by topography.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining accurate vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges stem from various factors influencing vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, such as the geographical positioning of meteorological stations. Most stations, except for a few located on ridges, are positioned in valleys. Additionally, there is a limited number of high-altitude stations, particularly on the western slope, which can affect the accuracy of the data obtained.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to update data collection instruments at meteorological stations periodically?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Updating data collection instruments is crucial as it ensures the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data. For instance, the station at the South-East Tibetan plateau has undergone updates to replace older models with newer ones, such as changing the temperature and humidity sensor from HMP45C to HMP155. These updates help maintain data precision and consistency over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variation in temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different slopes of a mountain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation is caused by the differing characteristics of the slopes. For instance, in the South-East Tibetan plateau, the western slope tends to have a higher temperature lapse rate compared to the eastern slope. This difference is attributed to the unique geographical and environmental conditions present on each slope, which influence the rate of temperature decrease with elevation and the pattern of precipitation changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the accuracy of meteorological data when sensor models are updated or replaced at a research station?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The meteorological data collected at the research station might experience variations in accuracy due to changes in sensor models. For example, the temperature and humidity sensors were updated from HMP45C to HMP155, and the pressure sensor from PTB220 to PTB110. Such updates can lead to differences in data due to variations in sensor sensitivity, calibration, and measurement precision, potentially affecting long-term data continuity and comparability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using data from multiple meteorological stations to study the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in a mountainous region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using data from multiple meteorological stations allows for a more comprehensive analysis of vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation. It helps identify spatial variations across different slopes and altitudes, providing insights into how these factors affect ecological and hydrological processes in the region. However, challenges may arise due to varying station locations and altitudes, potentially influencing the accuracy of gradient estimates.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind gathering basic meteorological data at high-altitude research stations in the Tibetan region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include supporting research in meteorology, atmospheric environment, and ecology, as well as providing reliable data for understanding vertical variations in temperature and precipitation, which are crucial for studying plant and animal distribution and hydrological modeling in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to explore the temperature and precipitation vertical gradients using meteorological stations on different slopes of a mountainous region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Exploring these gradients is important to enhance the understanding of how slope orientation affects vertical gradient changes in temperature and precipitation, which is essential for better comprehending the physiological and ecological characteristics of flora and fauna distribution with altitude, and for providing data support for hydrological simulations in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of using regression analysis to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients based on elevation and meteorological data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include determining accurate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients for different geographic units, which helps in understanding the climatic variations across different elevations and slopes, and provides data critical for ecological and environmental research in mountainous areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to ensure the accuracy of meteorological data collection in alpine environments, considering the challenges posed by varying altitudes and equipment changes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological data collection in alpine environments, like the one at 中科院藏东南站, involves using specific instruments such as temperature and humidity probes (HMP155), pressure sensors (PTB110), and wind speed sensors (0513), which were updated in 2020. The data is collected at a 10-minute resolution, with precipitation being recorded as a daily cumulative value. The accuracy is maintained by conducting regular updates to the equipment and ensuring the placement of stations both in ridge and valley areas to capture a range of environmental conditions.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate measurement of meteorological variables in mountainous regions like the South-East Tibetan plateau?
Enablement.Answer: In the South-East Tibetan plateau, meteorological variables are measured using station-based sensors that record temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation, and atmospheric pressure. The data is collected at a high temporal resolution of 10 minutes and involves the use of specific sensor models like HMP155 for temperature and humidity, PTB110 for pressure, and 0513 for wind speed. These instruments are positioned at various altitudes to capture the vertical gradients of climate variables.

Enablement.Question: How do the geographical and environmental conditions of the South-East Tibetan plateau enable unique data collection challenges and opportunities for climate research?
Enablement.Answer: The South-East Tibetan plateau presents unique data collection challenges and opportunities due to its varied altitudinal zones and complex topography, which impact the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation. The presence of different ecological zones like broadleaf forests and coniferous forests, along with high-altitude ridges, require strategically placed stations to accurately capture climatic variations. The geographical diversity allows for detailed studies on the altitudinal impacts on climate variables, but also requires careful consideration of station placement to ensure comprehensive data collection.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of historical meteorological data from multiple stations enhance the understanding of vertical temperature and precipitation gradients on the South-East Tibetan plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of historical meteorological data from multiple stations, such as those in Linzhi and Bome, enables a comprehensive understanding of vertical temperature and precipitation gradients by providing a long-term dataset for analysis. This data, spanning from 2013 to 2018, allows researchers to observe patterns and trends over time and across different altitudes. It facilitates regression analysis to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, thereby enhancing the understanding of how these variables change with elevation across different mountain slopes.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise in estimating precipitation gradients using data from multiple meteorological stations across varied topographies?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges could include the influence of topographic features on precipitation patterns, variations in station placement such as ridge versus valley locations, and the limited number of high-altitude stations, which might affect the accuracy of precipitation gradient estimates.

Judgmental.Question: How might the replacement of sensor models in 2020 impact the consistency and reliability of data collected for meteorological research?
Judgmental.Answer: The replacement of sensor models could impact the consistency and reliability of data by introducing variations in measurements between the old and new models. Researchers need to account for these changes to ensure that the data collected before and after 2020 are comparable and accurate for long-term studies.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using the vertical temperature and precipitation gradient data from multiple stations to understand climate patterns in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include the varying geographical placement of stations, with some located in valleys and others on ridges, which might affect the accuracy of vertical gradient estimations. Additionally, the limited number of stations on certain slopes could restrict the comprehensiveness of the findings.

Assertion.Question: I'm unclear about the challenges faced when collecting climate data in regions with varying altitudes and how these might affect data accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the placement of meteorological stations mostly in valleys rather than ridges, which can affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. Additionally, fewer stations located in high-altitude regions might impact the representativeness of data for those areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges in collecting accurate meteorological data in mountainous regions with varying altitudes.
Request/Directive.Answer: One challenge in collecting accurate meteorological data in mountainous regions like the South-East Tibetan plateau is the influence of different factors on the vertical lapse rate of temperature and precipitation gradient. Most meteorological stations, except for a few like mountain pass and tree line stations, are situated in valley areas, which may affect the accuracy of the lapse rate and precipitation gradient due to fewer high-altitude stations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be used to study climatic variability in high-altitude forested regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset includes temperature and precipitation daily values from 11 meteorological stations, including those at the South-East Tibetan plateau station and other sites, collected between 2013 and 2018. This dataset supports studies on climatic variability by providing data on temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different altitudes and slopes.
